cards.back: Representation of periodic signals as sum of harmonically related sinusoids: x(t) = Σcₖe^(jkω₀t). Decomposes into frequency components.

ω₀ = 2π/T = 2πf₀

Where T is the period. All harmonics are multiples: kω₀.
Frequency component at integer multiple of fundamental: kω₀. First harmonic = fundamental. k=0 is DC, k=2 is second harmonic.
DC component = average value: c₀ = (1/T)∫x(t)dt. The zero-frequency component. Constant offset.
Only odd harmonics (1, 3, 5, ...) due to half-wave symmetry. Amplitudes decay as 1/k.

cards.front: Why are sinusoids eigenfunctions of LTI?
cards.back: Sinusoid in, sinusoid out at same frequency. Only amplitude and phase change. LTI cannot create new frequencies.
Discrete (line) spectrum. Energy only at harmonic frequencies kω₀, shown as sticks in frequency plot.
x(t) = -x(t+T/2) means only odd harmonics. Even harmonics are zero. Square, triangle waves have this.
x(t) bounded, finite discontinuities, finite extrema per period. Most practical signals satisfy. Series converges to function (or midpoint at jumps).
